awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves research in the area of analytic number theory.  An important class of problems in this area concerns L-functions, which encode arithmetic information.   One example of an L-function is the Riemann zeta function, which controls the distribution of prime numbers.  One of the investigator's main goals is to make progress on the value distribution and zeros of L-functions.  Concurrently, one hopes to use such information to extract applications to problems in arithmetic.  While these topics are of intrinsic interest in mathematics, progress in number theory has had important applications in cryptography and theoretical computer science.  

More specifically, the investigator will continue his investigations on moments and value distribution of L-functions, extending in particular his recent work with Radziwill. The investigator will also continue work on multiplicative functions, in collaboration with Granville, Harper, and Koukoulopoulos.  Besides these two main projects, the investigator will work with coauthors on various problems at the interface of analysis, number theory, and combinatorics, and continue his work in training graduate students in this area.

por.por_cntn:
The PI continued his research in multiplicative number theory and the analytic theory of L-functions while supported on this grant.   The long term goals of the area are to understand properties of fundamental arithmetic objects such as prime numbers, and to study zeta and L-functions which package information about such arithmetic objects and may be studied analytically.  

During the grant period, some highlights of the research carried out include: 

1.  Work with Robert Lemke Oliver on a curious bias in the last digits of consecutive primes.  This work explained the empirical fact that consecutive primes prefer not to have the same last digit.  The work received media attention, with a Quanta article devoted to this phenomenon. 

2.  Completion of a project with Granville and Harper, developing a new approach to a fundamental theorem of Halasz and its consequences within multiplicative number theory. 

3. Work with Arguin, Belius, Bourgade and Radziwill on the distribution of local maxima of the Riemann zeta function.  This work made progress towards a conjecture of Fyodorov, Hiary and Keating, and combines ideas from probability theory and analytic number theory. 

4.  Work with Jesse Thorner on developing a weak subconvexity result for L-functions in great generality. 

5.  Work on classifying integral factorial ratios, giving a new treatment of examples that go back to Chebyshev. 

Brief descriptions of other achievements from the grant are provided in the final report. 

In addition to these research activities, the PI continued to mentor students (undergraduate and graduate) and postdoctoral researchers during the grant period.  Several undergraduates worked on senior theses; one exceptional student was Katy Woo, who is currently a Ph. D. student at Princeton University.  A number of graduate students at Stanford received their Ph. D. advised by the PI during this period, including Alexandra Florea, Zeb Brady, Chandrasekhar Raju, Sarah Peluse, Ho Chung Siu.  The PI also mentored postdoctoral researchers Lemke Oliver, Jesse Thorner, and Asif Zaman during the grant period.  

Research during the grant period was disseminated through various journal publications, and lectures by the PI.  One highlight is a 10 lecture CBMS course on "The distribution of values of zeta and L-functions" delivered at Oxford, Mississippi.  The PI also gave a large number of talks ranging from public lectures to a general audience, talks for undergraduates, to research seminars.
